title: Athelney, Somerset
description: In this first ever episode of Time Team, Tony and the team travel to Athelney in Somerset to investigate a series of hills (once islands in a bog) that became Alfred The Great last defensive positions after a series of losses to invading Viking forces. It is also the place Alfred began the great rally that saw him re-conquer most Wessex and laid the foundations of the nation that was to become England

title: Ribchester, Lancashire
description: Ribchester in Lancashire has been known for some time as a site of a Roman fort. The Time Team arrive in the town to answer two questions, one is to consolidate all the previous excavations on the site, and the second to define the outline of a possible older wooden fort that is thought to have been in the area.

title: Much Wenlock, Shropshire
description: The Time Team go to the small town of Much Wenlock, after they receive a letter from a resident explains a recent excavation uncovered possibly the oldest house in the town. What they discover is the remains of an old Saxon village transitioning into a larger newer Norman settlement.

title: Llangorse Lake, Powys
description: The Time Team travel to Brecon Beacons in Wales, they have come to investigate a small man-made island in Llangorse Lake. Locals tell many strange legends including hearing the sounds of Church bells echoing across the body of water at night. The Team want to know who built the island and try to find evidence to support the stories of it eventual fall into disuse.

title: Finlaggan, Islay
description: The Time Team travel to a group of islands on the western side of Scotland to investigate a culture known as the "Lords of the Isls" - who ruled the islands 1000 years ago. The team joins a group from the Scottish National University who've been working in the area for some five years uncovering the history of these people. What the Time Team discovers throws the whole excavation into a new light and suggests people may have lived in the area thousands of years prior.

title: Hylton Castle, Sunderland
description: The Time Team visit Hylton Castle near Sunderland. A local group want to redevelop the local area as a tourist attraction but don't want to disturb any hidden structures.

title: Tockenham, Wiltshire
description: Tockenham village, in the Wiltshire countryside. Despite the fact that there are no Roman remains in Tockenham, the village's 15th century church, St Giles, has a small pagan Roman statue embedded in one of its outer walls.

title: Lambeth Palace, London
description: The Time Team traveled to Lambet Palace in the heart of London. They are trying to unravel the enigma of why the Romans crossed the Thames in a different area to where they developed the city. The team needs to employ some extreme archeology to try an understand what the Romans where thinking

title: Winterbourne Gunner, Wiltshire
description: The Time Team travel to Winterbourne Gunner in Wiltshire to investigate a housing development that has come to a halt because of an alarming number of Saxon graves found in the area They successfully work their way through the maze of finds but in doing so discover what seems to be a whole new layer of history in the town.

title: Boleigh, Cornwall
description: The Time Team travels to Boleigh, Cornwall so as to investigate an underground structure known as a foogoo. Cornwall and other Celtic cultural areas have many examples of these caves, but to date no one has figure out what they were for. The team has three days to try and resolve the issue.

title: Stanton Harcourt, Oxfordshire
description: Stanton Harcourt is built on a series of old river channels where the Thames flowed 200,000 years ago. At the site of a local land fill huge numbers of bones belonging to a range of extinct animals have been found. The Time Team come to aid hard pressed local diggers in locating the the exact river channel hence allow them to reconstruct the ancient landscape.

title: Templecombe, Somerset
description: Templecombe Somerset is the site of a priory that dates back to the 12th century. The exact location of the original building has been confused by later construction. The Time Team set themselves the task of untangling the ruins and coming to grips with the history of the location.

title: Teignmouth, Devon
description: Close to the medieval port of Teignmouth a ship wreck over three hundred years old has been found. Despite everyone's best efforts no one has so far identified the ship or where it may have come from. The Time Team has 3 days to unravel the mystery.

title: Navan, County Armagh
description: The team travel to Northern Ireland to the site of the Navan fort, a series of complex earth works dating back to the earliest human occupation. They are looking to confirm a persistent legend that the site was the power base of an early king and he at one point had three separate strong holds in the area even though only two have ever been found.

title: Lavenham, Suffolk
description: For years a Suffolk farmer has gathered hundreds of pieces of Roman pottery, jewelry and coins from one particular field on his land. Where did all this rich material come from and why is it so concentrated in one area?

title: St Mary's City, Maryland, USA
description: Time Team follow in the footsteps of some of the first English settlers in America. The journey takes them to the historic landing site of St Mary's City, Maryland to unearth some important finds.

roles.char: Himself - Archaeological Curator, St. Mary's City
Himself - Director of Research, St. Mary's City
Himself - Chief Archaeologist, St. Mary's City

title: Launceston, Cornwall
description: The history of a female skeleton found in Cornwall. Was she a leper from a 13th century colony, a casualty of the Civil War, a plague victim or put to death after being tried at the Launceston Assizes in the late I6th or early 17th century.

title: Soho, Birmingham
description: Tony Robinson and Mick Aston call in the experts to try and locate one of the most important sites in the history of the Industrial Revolution - Matthew Boulton's 18th century mint.

title: Govan, Glasgow
description: Several intriguing stone sculptures have been discovered in the graveyard of the parish church. No less than 30 of these large, intricately carved gravestones in two distinct styles. Who was buried here, by whom, and why.

title: Malton, Yorkshire
description: The intrepid archaeological treasure hunters, led by Tony Robinson, head for Malton in North Yorkshire where a swathe of nettle-infested jungle conceals 2,000 years of English history including a Roman fort.

title: Netheravon, Wiltshire
description: Time Team are inside a partially abandoned army barracks in Nethcravon. But It's not military memorabilia they're after. In 1907, a Colonel Hawley found part of a mosaic in the grounds which he believed was part of a Roman villa.

title: Richmond, Surrey
description: Trumpeters House in Richmond, near London. Records show it was the site of a royal palace from the time of Edward III through to Elizabeth I, who died there. Destroyed during Cromwell's Commonwealth, the site has lain unexcavated.

title: Greylake, Somerset
description: In Iron Age times, the lowlands of Somerset were marshland. Boats couldn't cross the expansive swamps so wooden walkways stretching for hundreds of yards were built. TT find out if early 1920s reports will re-reveal peat-preserved remains.

title: Sanday, Orkney
description: Schoolchildren on the Orkney island of Sanday asked Time Team to investigate local mounds that could, reputedly, be of Viking origin. This is the first time the Team have looked for Norse archaeological finds.

roles.char: Herself - Wrote letter to Time Team

title: Turkdean, Gloucestershire
description: 3 days of live excavation. The weekend ended with evidence of a Romano-British villa complex that is one of the largest ever found in Britain. This programme is an edited version of that weekend.

title: Deya, Mallorca, Spain
description: This overseas visit is to Mallorca Spain. In pursuit of the Beaker people, an enigmatic culture thought by some to have been responsible for the introduction of metal work into Britain.

roles.char: Himself - Deya Archaeological Museum Research Centre
Himself - Deya Archaeological Museum Research Centre

title: Aston Eyre, Shropshire
description: Time Team's efforts are concentrated as much above the ground as beneath as they travel to Aston Eyre, Shropshire where a farmhouse converted from a medieval gatehouse is just the starting point for three days of hard work.

title: Downpatrick, County Down
description: One of Ireland's most sacred sites where St Patrick, patron saint of All Ireland, set up his first church. On Cathedral Hill sits a magnificent church renovated from its medieval origins in the 18th century.

title: High Worsall, North Yorkshire
description: Time Team goes to Teesside. It has been known for years that just yards from the current village is the site of a medieval village but why it was abandoned so suddenly, literally disappearing off the map.

title: Burslem, Stoke-on-Trent
description: In the late 18th century, a young man opened his first factory in the village of Burslem, later part of Stoke-on-Trent. The man was Josiah Wedgwood. Time Team try and find if anything remained of these early ceramic manufacturing premises.

title: Papcastle, Cumbria
description: Papcastle, a small village outside Cockermouth in Cumbria, boasts a Roman fort. But when a local resident got in touch with Time Team about some substantial stonework he had dug out of his garden the moment had come to look beyond the fort.

roles.char: Herself - University of Newcastle upon Tyne

title: Thetford, Norfolk
description: The site of Thetford Grammar School in Norfolk may today be a place for exams and play, but in the 13th century, a large Dominican friary was here and before that, for a mere 24 years, a Norman cathedral.

title: Cheddar Gorge, Somerset
description: Time Team was invited by the Marquess of Bath, owner of one side of the gorge, to investigate Cooper's Hole to see if they could find evidence of Palaeolithic human activity.

title: Plympton, Devon
description: A village that had had its heyday in the Middle Ages. They looked in back gardens and public spaces, under stairs, in cellars and in attics for clues to the village's antiquity, but their biggest surprise came in the grounds of a nunnery.

title: Smallhythe, Kent
description: Smallhythe is now a village amid fields. The nearest body of water being a Sewer and a drainage ditch. But in the 15th and 16th centuries, it was the site of a bustling shipbuilding industry right next to the mile-wide River Rother.

title: Beauport Park, Sussex
description: Down a bridleway within a dense Sussex wood, a Roman bath house stands, with walls head-high, completely forgotten for centuries.

title: Reedham, Marshes, Norfolk
description: In February 1944, two American 'Flying Fortresses' crashed into each other only a few miles from their home base, on their way back from a bombing raid over Germany. One of the aircraft tumbled into a marsh.

title: Turkdean, Gloucestershire II
description: This year, for the first time revisiting an excavation, S5E4, the Team came back to the site to see if they could make sense of the spectacular geophysics results that they had not had time to investigate during the live dig.

title: Kemerton, Worcestershire
description: Bredon Hill, one of the most important Iron Age hillforts in the country. Combine this geographical location with aerial photographs of extensive cropmarks that hinted at a Bronze Age settlement.

title: Bawsey, Norfolk
description: Time Team are joined by guests Sandi Toksvig and Hugh Fearnley Whittingstall. They unearth fine Saxon jewelry, a stash of Norman pottery and a medieval murder victim near Kings Lynn.

title: Nevis, West Indies: Part 1
description: The Time Team go to the West Indies and the island of Nevis. Their intention is to uncover the remains of a number of plantation houses that now are no more than ruins. The dig is important because the whole are is soon to be developed as a tourist complex with golf course.

roles.char: Himself - Potteries Museum, Stoke - on - Trent
Himself - Parents worked in the sugar industry

title: Nevis, West Indies: Part 2
description: On the second part of their West Indian trip focuses on finding the original settlement of Jamestown. Local legend suggests the town was destroyed in a tsunami, but the Time Team are not so convinced.

roles.char: Himself - Potteries Museum, Stoke - on - Trent

title: Denia, Spain
description: Time Team travel to the small port of Denia in Spain to show what life was like 1000 years ago, when Denia was an Islamic settlement run by a pirate king.

roles.char: Himself - Municipal Service of Urban Archaeology

title: Cirencester, Gloucestershire
description: Around 1700 years ago, Corinium - modern day Cirencester - was the second most important city in Roman Britain after Londinium. Time Team arrive to excavate in the gardens of properties in Chester Street near to the centre of old Corinium.

title: Wierre-Effroy, France
description: On 23 May 1940, Spitfire pilot Paul Klipsch flew across the Channel for his first and last day of combat. He crashed in France and was buried in the local cemetery. Time Team excavate the Spitfire and tell the story of Klipsch's last hours.

title: Waddon, Dorset
description: Time Team descend on the tiny village of Wadden in Dorset. Neighbours discovered a huge amount of pottery in their gardens. The pottery dated from Medieval, Roman and the Iron Age. What lies beneath five houses of the village?

roles.char: Himself - Curator of Archaeology Dorchester Museum

title: Birdoswald, Cumbria
description: The Time Team travel to Hadrian's Wall the world's longest Roman monument for the once in a lifetime investigation of A Roman burial site attached to the fort know as Birdoswald. While the excavation of the cemetery goes as expected they stumble on evidence of something far more exciting.

title: Elveden, Suffolk
description: In search of the real-life Flintstones at one of Britain's early Stone Age sites. A holiday camp in Suffolk. The site dates back 400k years when our ancestors shared the country with lions, rhinos & elephants - but definitely no dinosaurs.

title: Coventry, West Midlands
description: The Time Team go to Coventry to try and locate the layout of the city's first cathedral. The team does a great job locating finds in a chaotic dig criss crossed with power cables and various plumbing lines.

roles.char: Himself - Senior Conservation Officer, Coventry Council

title: Basing House, Hampshire
description: The Team rubs shoulders with royalty when they visit Basing House in Hampshire. It was once one of grandest homes in Tudor England and a haunt of Henry VIII and Elizabeth I - until it was destroyed by Cromwell during the Civil War.

title: Flag Fen, Cambridgeshire
description: The Team travel back to the Bronze Age to Flag Fen in Cambridgeshire. The fenland bog is home to one of the most important archaeological 'wet-sites' in the country, where the soggy conditions help preserve 3000-year-old buried timbers.

title: Sutton, Herefordshire
description: Time Team head for Herefordshire in search of the palace of the great Anglo-Saxon leader, King Offa, who ruled the kingdom of Mercia from 757 to 796. Records show that a palace was in the area but its exact location has never been found.

title: Greenwich, London
description: The Time Team excavate Roman ruins in Greenwich park. The ruins were last investigated over a 100 years ago, but the purpose of the buildings was never confirmed. The team also take the time to check an alternative theory about the route of Wattling Street.

roles.char: Himself - Birkbeck College, University of London

title: Hartlepool, County Durham
description: 1,200 years ago a thriving community of monks and nuns were trying to convert the pagans to Christianity. But the Saxon monastery disappeared after 200 years and lay forgotten until workmen unearthed human bones and grave markers in 1833.

title: York, Yorkshire
description: The Team travel to York to excavate 3 sites from 3 different historical periods. They find a Roman skeleton with hobnail boots, a Viking's discarded leather shoe and the pillars of a monastic hospital. But what does this evidence reveal?

title: Normanton, Lincolnshire
description: On the surface it looks just like any other large Lincolnshire field. But when a pipe was laid across it a couple of years previously the trench dug then revealed a number of shallow graves.

title: Alderton, Northamptonshire
description: A couple of years ago, local man Derek Batten was driving through the village of Alderton, near Northampton, when he was surprised to see a sign advertising a castle and moat for sale.

title: Llygadwy, Wales
description: In a secluded valley in Wales, what may be a medieval or even Roman trackway leads down to a natural spring. In the middle a megalith, a large standing stone, perhaps 3000 years older than the track and what appears to be a Neolithic tomb.

title: Waltham, Gloucestershire
description: Waltham field, in the village of Whittington, five miles from Cheltenham. Alerted by Gloucester County Archaeology, the Team have come in search of a Roman villa.

title: Blaenavon, South Wales
description: Looking for the world's first railway viaduct. 40 metres long, 10 metres high and 10 arches built in 1790. Yet within 25 years it had disappeared from the landscape. There was no record of it having been demolished so where has it gone?

title: Rycote, Oxfordshire
description: Time Team try to find the remains of a grand country house that once played host to five reigning monarchs. What was left of the original Tudor mansion, built in the 1520s and believed to have burnt down and been abandoned in 1745.

roles.char: Himself - Chairman of Garden History Society

title: Salisbury Plain, Wiltshire
description: As well as being the British Army's biggest training ground it is one of Europe's most extensive areas of undisturbed archaeology believed to contain the remains of settlements spanning both the Iron Age and the Roman era.

title: Basildon, Berkshire
description: In 1838, navvies laying Brunel's Great Western Railway found two Roman floor mosaics. The mosaics were broken up and the site almost forgotten until recent aerial photographs revealed a series of crop marks in the fields by the railway.

title: Alveston, Gloucestershire
description: Holy Island, close to the English Scottish border was a significant religious center until the dissolution in the 1580's. The Time Team seek to understand the history of a specific point known as Palace field, while it is known there is a structure there, what it is has remained a mystery.

roles.char: Himself - English Heritage: Iron Age Expert

title: Holy Island, Northumberland
description: The Time Team travel to Holy Island on the Scottish English border. Their mission is to excavate an open field that is locally known as the palace' No one alive today knows the reason for the name, but the team intend to find out.

roles.char: Himself - National Museums & Galleries of Wales

title: Bridgnorth, Shropshire
description: A tower is all that's left of a castle built 900 years ago. Occupied for around 5 centuries until it fell to Cromwell in the English Civil War. It survives today, leaning at an angle of 15 degrees. 3 times more than the tower of Pisa.

title: Canterbury, Kent
description: The Time Team travel to Canterbury to understand the religious evolution of the city. They are looking for evidence of early Roman temples to the establishment in the first settlements of Monks in England.

roles.char: Himself - Dep Dir: Canterbury Archaeological Trust

title: Winchester, Hampshire
description: Winchester the once capital of England was also the site of one of the biggest leper colony in the country. Time Team travel to the site of the colony to try and to recreate the lives these poor people lived.

title: Vauxhall, London
description: On the edge of the river Thames, a series of posts driven into the riverbed have been found. Also 2 Bronze Age spearheads. Are these the remains of London's first bridge or the supports of a platform where Bronze-Age people made offerings.

title: Ancaster, Lincolnshire
description: The Lincolnshire town of Ancaster lies on Ermine Street, which is a major Roman road heading north from London. The only remains visible today are some earth banks and ditches, which have been dated to the 4th century. What was here before?

title: Kinlochbervie, North West Scotland
description: Originally discovered by divers from RAF Lossiemouth, an amazing shipwreck lies some 20 metres down on the seabed just off the coast of Kinlochbervie, in north-west Scotland.

title: Chicksands, Bedfordshire
description: A military base in the heart of Bedfordshire is home to the joint armed services intelligence departments. The Team was invited to try to discover more about the history of the officers mess which was once a part of a 13th century monastery.

title: Ironbridge Gorge, Shropshire
description: In the village of Leighton the Team is investigating a particularly interesting cellar; the archaeology could take us back nearly 400 years. The cellar, based in a pub, contains the remains of a blast furnace - used for making iron.

title: Cheshunt, Hertfordshire
description: Back in the 1950s & 60s, 2 families of amateur archaeologists excavated some Roman remains in what is now a park in Cheshunt. They were asked to keep quiet about it because the British Museum believed this might be an important Roman site.

title: Helford, Cornwall
description: Two large earthworks can be seen at Gear and Caer Vallack in Cornwall. Sited on top of adjacent hills, they were thought by Victorian archaeologists to be Iron-Age hillforts but little is understood about their origins.

title: High Ercall, Shropshire
description: High Ercall Hall, in Shropshire, is the very picture of rural tranquility today, but 355 years ago, at the height of the English Civil War, more than 200 Royalist troops were crammed inside the walls fighting for their lives.

title: Greenwich, London
description: The Time Team visit Greenwich Palace, built by Henry VIII father and extensively developed by the greatest of Tudor Kings. The team is looking for evidence of two major buildings, long since demolished to build the famous Greenwich hospital.

title: Kew Gardens, London
description: Kew Garden home of George III favorite palace, however after 250 years all that remains of this wonderful building is a sundial. The Time team has only three days to survey the remains of the building, and unlock all its buried secrets. But first they have to find the building first

roles.char: Himself - Head of Visitor Attractions: Castle Howard

title: Syon House, London
description: The Time Team travel to Syon House in London to try and locate a huge Monastery that dates back to the time of Henry VI. Today all that can be seen is open lawn. In the past the team has failed many times to locate similar structures in such situations. This time they are sure they will find success.

title: Whitestaunton, Somerset
description: Whitestaunton is the site of a 130 year old mystery. The Victorian owners of the site unearthed ruins that suggested an old Roman Villa existed on the site. Recent re-investigation suggests the building is not a Villa, which begs the question, what is it?.

title: Oakamoor, Staffordshire
description: A team of archaeologists have just three days to excavate the site of an Elizabethan blast furnace after finding clues in a test pit dug as part of Time Team Big Dig. The team also explore medieval furnaces at nearby East Wall and try smelting their own iron.

title: Chenies Manor House, Buckinghamshire
description: This manor house was extended into a palace prior to Henry V111 first visit in 1534. But less than half of it remains. The current owner since the 1950's wants to know what it used to look like.

roles.char: Herself - R C A H M S Field Liaison Officer
Himself - Head of Archaeology: Tyne and Wear Museums
Himself - Archaeologist: Tyne and Wear Museums
Himself - Gordon's Lodge Archaeological Field School
Himself - Gordon's Lodge Archaeological Field School

title: Manchester
description: The Time Team head for Manchester England to uncover the oldest cotton mill in the city, the Arkwright Mill. The building is important because Richard Arkwright used a number of cutting edge technologies to drive the mill. To understand the building the team needs to find the position of various steam engines and water wheels. A seemingly easy process is complicated in the knowledge the building was destroyed and rebuilt many times

title: Utrecht, Netherlands
description: The Time Team head to Utrecht Netherlands to investigate a combined Roman fort and trading center. There main interest is a previously excavated Roman ship. Whats starts as a routine investigation quickly develops into a dig that will forever change what we thought we knew of the Romans and the vessels they sailed in

title: Isle of Man
description: The Time Team visit the Isl Of Man to excavate the last remaining keeill, or small Christian Chapel on the island. What they uncover is a cemetery that had been in use for over 1500 years. Among their finds are some items so rare they may redefined the history of the island and be completely unique in the careers of the archeologists involved in the project.

title: Blacklands, Somerset
description: The Time Team investigate a Roman Villa found at Blacklands Somerset. Conventional history tells that the Britons fought against the Romans and refused to allow many of their cultural standards to be Romanized. Rather than finding a culture in conflict they discover some things about the villa that may eventually rewrite the history of early Britain

title: Hooke Court, Dorset
description: Hooke Court in Dorset now a school is visited by the Time Team. Their main concern is to unravel the hectic construction that seems to have occurred on the site. Although they are interested in features dating from the English Civil War. With more than 5 reconstructions of the buildings and at least one devastating fire; making out the history of the site becomes problematic

title: Anglesey, North Wales
description: In early 2006 an aerial photographic survey of Anglesey produced a remarkable image. On the slopes south of the town of Amlwch approximately four miles from the island's north coast - a large pentangular earthwork could be seen.

title: The Shorncliffe Redoubt, Folkestone
description: The team investigate the history of the Shorncliffe Redoubt, piecing together how its design and use as a training ground for light infantry troops helped to develop the modern army and defend the coast against invasion by 'the old enemy'.

title: Stilton, Cambridgeshire
description: In 2006, Richard Landy discovered an almost complete ceramic Roman cheese press. What made it all the more special is where he found it - washing out of the side of a two-metre-deep ditch in Stilton, Cambridgeshire.

title: Wicken, Northamptonshire
description: Wicken, in Northamptonshire, appears to be a typical English village, with a church and manor house. But back in the medieval era there were two churches and two manor houses here, making up two separate villages. Wick Hamon and Wick Dive.

title: Warburton, Cheshire
description: Moss Brow Farm in Warburton, Cheshire, had been the focus of intense study for a decade. In that time, the site had produced a rare snake's head bracelet, a silver denarius and a collection of Roman metalwork. TT want to find more.

roles.char: Himself - Head of Archaeology: National Museums Liverpool

title: Dotton, Devon
description: The last working mill in the village closed down in 1946, however, and in 1968 the building was ordered to be demolished by the local council because the wheel pit was regarded as a danger to children.

title: Chesham Bois, Buckinghamshire
description: The owner of a Chesham Bois House, is a keen gardener. She's turned up 17th-century and medieval tiles beneath the greenhouse, uncovered medieval pottery in the flowerbeds, and noticed strange lumps and bumps at the bottom of the garden.

title: Godstone, Surrey
description: The site is positioned close to a Roman road connecting London to the south coast and has never been excavated. Local archaeologists have wondered what lies beneath the surface for many years, and called in Time Team to help them find out.

title: Codnor Castle, Derbyshire
description: The Time team travel to Codnor Castle in Derbyshire to try and piece together the history of the castle that is nearly a 1000 years old. Among a series of wonderful discoveries they find something in the moat that takes everyone's breath away.

title: Binchester, County Durham
description: The team investigates an old gatehouse in Durham. They have been invited by the current owners to try and unravel the history of the building and what it was designed to protect.

title: Barra, Outer Hebrides
description: In Ireland a series of strange ditch like constructions are investigated to identify who may have built one of the largest promontory fort in Ireland. The Time team become almost overwhelmed by the amount of finds and what those finds tell us about the builders.

roles.char: Himself - Finds Liaison Officer, North East
Himself - Inspector of Ancient Monuments, Cadw

title: Friars Wash, Hertfordshire
description: The Time Team investigates a series of strange marking identified in a field in Hartfordshire. They think they may be dealing with one or possibly two Roman period religious temples. What they discover exceeds their expectations and lead to discoveries that rewrite the history of England.

title: Scargill Castle, County Durham
description: The team investigates an old gatehouse in Durham. The current owners have Invited them to try and unravel the history of the building and what it was designed to protect.

title: Knockdhu, Co Antrim
description: In Ireland a series of strange ditch like constructions are investigated to identify who may have built one of the largest promontory fort in Ireland. The Time team become almost overwhelmed by the amount of finds they make and what those finds tell us about the builders.

roles.char: Herself - Head of Early Prehistory: National Museums Scotland

title: Caerwent, South Wales
description: Caerwent is the most well preserved Roman town in Britian. Located in Wales it has been dug and studied for over 100 years. The Time Team have been invited to dig a previously untouched section of the town in search of what is believed to be the biggest villa in the area.

title: Rise Hill, Cumbria
description: In Rise Hill Yorkshire are the remains of one of the last railroads built by the Navies, itinerant construction workers who moved from site to site looking for work. As much as is known about construction techniques etc, virtually nothing is known about the life they led in these remote locations.

roles.char: Himself - Colworth Science Park Archaeology Society
Himself - Colworth Science Park Archaeology Society

title: Blythburgh, Suffolk
description: New owners of a house in Blythburgh explored their shed and found a cupboard full of human skulls. Are these remains part of what's lurking amongst the shrubs and trees: the ruins of a medieval priory that has lain hidden for years?

title: Westminster
description: During the 19th century, restoration work at Westminster Abby uncovered a previously unknown section of the church. The Time Team begin excavating the area to try and determine the origin and use of the unknown section. As they do they begin to make discoveries far older and more important.

title: Baliscate Chapel, Tobermory, Isle of Mull
description: The team travel to the Isle of Mull to investigate a series of strange structures found deep in a forest. There is suspicion the site may be a previously unknown Christian Church, or it could be a simple farmers dwelling.

title: Piercebridge, County Durham
description: Piercebridge is the site of an extensive Roman fort designed to protect a crossing of the river Tees. The Time Team are looking at the many anomalies in the area, such as why there appears to be three separate bridges across the river and the collection of precious objects discovered in the river itself.

title: Sutton Courtenay, Oxfordshire
description: The Time to travel to Sutton Coutenay in Oxfordshire to excavate an old Saxon settlement. The area is known from photos of crop markings, and there is a suspicion the holy grail of archeology may be found, a royal Saxon Hall.

title: Hopton Castle, Shropshire
description: Hopton Castle was the site of a massacre during the English civil war. There is only one account of the battle and subsequent slaughter of the defenders. The Time Team decides to investigate the site and try to establish how much of the account is actually true.

roles.char: Himself - The Royal Logistic Corps Museum

title: Cunetio, Wiltshire
description: In 1940 aerial photos of a field revealed the location of a lost Roman town. Later huge coin hoards were found and the Time Team decide to explore why the money was there and what was the towns real function.

title: Norman Cross, Cambridgeshire
description: Norman Cross is possibly the world's first purpose built POW camp. Although the site was closed in 1816, no archaeological work has ever been done. The Time Team have three days to discover and map the shape of the camp and uncover what life was like for POWs during the time.

roles.char: Himself - The Royal Logistic Corps Museum

title: Tregruk Castle, South Wales
description: The team goes to an enigmatic castle site in Wales. The layout of the walls and the central keep are well understood at Tregruk Castle, but there are huge blank spaces within the wall that seem to have had no purpose.

roles.char: Himself - Castles Expert, University of Exeter
Himself - Historian, University of Wales, Newport
Himself - Inspector of Ancient Monuments, Cadw

title: Burford, Oxfordshire
description: After a chance discovery of Saxon pottery in the town Burford, the Time Team attempt to unravel the history of this medieval town. With the help of a group of school children they put together a time line 1500 years long.

title: Portsmouth, Hampshire
description: The Governor's Green is an historic part of the ancient city of Portsmouth. Before the Governors house was built in the 18th century a series of churches and pilgrims hospitals were on the site. And this is what Time Team wants to explore.

title: Litlington, Cambridgeshire
description: A hundred years ago digging in an open field suggested the remains of a large Roman villa could be found near the town of Litlington. As always nothing is as it seems when the Time Team become involved.

title: Dinmore, Herefordshire
description: Evidence seems to show a huge hill fort near the town of Dinmore. The Time investigates the site and begins to unravel exactly what the site represents. Even members of the team seem divided on what exactly the massive engineering work completed 3000 years ago was for.

title: Bedford Purlieus Wood, Cambridgeshire
description: In 1825, Edmund Tyrell Artis claims to have found Roman statues, buildings and even burials in a wood near Cambridgeshire. In 2005 Artis' site has been rediscovered, and the Team have 3 days to get some answers.

title: Tottiford, Devon
description: Tony and the time team get a rare opportunity to investigate a site after a local dam in Dartmoor is drained for repairs. The team is challenged to unravel a history that dates back to the earliest settlement of the United kingdom. They discover evidence the site had been used constantly for 4000 years, but to their surprise some of the structures they find seem completely out of place

title: West Langton, Leicestershire
description: The Time team investigate a well known site, presumed to be used for Saxon burial rituals in West Langton Leicestershire. While there they explore the funeral practices of the Saxons, and recreate a burial using one of the Time Team members. As the three day dig continues they begin to find evidence the Saxons where not the only people to use the site, this challenges all involved to piece together a history of hundreds of years of use of a small non-descript piece of countryside

title: High Ham, Somerset
description: The time team travel to High Ham in Somerset. Victorian excavations of the area uncovered a series mosaics that indicate a Roman Villa existed on the site. The team begins the job of untangling exactly what was on the site. While there is evidence of the Romans, there are other things that tell a much wider and in some ways sadder story.

title: Les Gellettes, Jersey
description: The Time Team travel to the Channel Islands. This time they explore the ruins of the German occupation of the islands during WW2. They find evidence of both military defenses built around the islands and many of the day to day activates that made up life for German forces during the occupation.

roles.char: Himself - Curator Royal Logistic Corps Museum

title: Derwentcote, County Durham
description: Tony Robinson and his time team travel to Derwentcote near Newcastle in England. They have three days to investigate the ruins of an iron and steel works that produced world class metal from the early 1700's to the 1850's Their interest is based on the number of different processes developed in the area during the time, culminating in evidence the site was much older than first thought

title: Castor, Cambridgeshire
description: The Time Team head to the town of Castor to dig in the grounds of a Church looking for remains of a substantial Roman complex. Complicating the excavation is the work of Edmund Artist who took detailed measurements and dug the area 150 years ago. They need to first find the ruins, and try and understand and confirm what Artist saw.

title: Groby, Leicestershire
description: The Time Team visits the ruins of the home of the Grey family, and property the family had lived on for nearly 800 years. The team tries to establish the history of a castle built on the site in the 12 century.

roles.char: Herself - Historian and Author 'The White Queen'

title: Mont Orgueil, Jersey
description: Mont Orgueil in Jersey is a well known fortification that has history stemming back to the 12th Century. The Time Team's job is to unravel where the series of 17th Century extensions absorbed the original medieval construction, and what the castle originally looked like in the time of the Normans.

title: Llancaiach Fawr, South Wales
description: The team visits Llancaiach Manor in southern Wales to investigate a series of strange structures found in the 1970s. What begins as a straight forward search for a missing manor house turns up a far more complex and interesting story.

title: Buck Mill, Somerset
description: There is evidence at Buck Mill Somerset of an ancient water wheel and mill. As the team begin to explore the site, discoveries ask more questions than answers given.

title: Bamburgh, Northumberland
description: The Time Team travels to Bamburgh Castle. A place once thought to be a major power base for the Saxon kings in the region. Although a village and Saxon graveyard have been located, no evidence of the original Saxon fortifications has been found.

title: Gateholm Island, Pembrokeshire
description: Tony Robinson and the Team visit a tiny windswept island off the coast of Wales. The only way to get to it is by rigging a 500-metre zip wire way above the wave-lashed rocks.

title: Bitterley, Shropshire
description: The village's school and cottages cluster prettily around the green. But the village church and the manor house lie more than half a mile away, on the other side of a lumpy, bumpy empty field.

title: Dunwich, Suffolk
description: A village that's falling off the edge of the UK. Coastal erosion has eaten away most of this settlement. Before the place is lost to the sea, there's a last chance to find out more about the lost origins of this dramatically situated town.

title: Newmarket, Suffolk
description: The birthplace of horse racing. Search for the earliest archaeological traces of the sport of kings. Dig in the historic town for the remains of King Charles II's racing stables - arguably the world's first stables dedicated for racing.

title: Beadnell, Northumberland
description: Tony and the team are in the village of Beadnell on the Northumbrian coast, to explore an unusual promontory, from which mysterious fragments of human bone have emerged over the last few years.

title: Swansea, West Glamorgan
description: Tony and the team are in Swansea. The city used to lead the world in copper smelting, but today there's almost nothing to be seen of this unique heritage. They team investigate one of the very first copper works, White Rock.

title: Earls Colne, Essex
description: The Time Team visit Earls Colne in Essex to try and uncover traces of a 12th Priory founded by the De Vere family. Now a luxury home, the owner hopes the Time team can explain many of the anomalies in the grounds.

roles.char: Herself - Royal Holloway, University of London

title: Kenfig, South Wales
description: 800 years ago the people of Kenfig on the south coast of Wales thought they had built the perfect town. The town appears to have been a thriving commercial success but then it vanished, leaving just a few castle walls to mark its existence.

title: Caerleon, South Wales
description: The Time Team visit a set of Roman ruins in Caerlon in South Wales. The area was always known for it's extensive construction work, but what the Time Team uncover that changes everything.

title: Castle Hill, Crewkerne, Somerset
description: For generations a family of Somerset farmers have been wondering if there was ever actually a castle on top of 'Castle Hill'. Records show there was a Norman castle in the area, but they are not clear about exactly where.

title: Clipstone, Nottinghamshire
description: Sherwood Forest. Residents of Clipstone believe ruins in a field relate to tales of Robin Hood and Bad King John. The history books describe these walls as the remains of a royal hunting lodge. But the locals believe it was a palace.

title: Burials Compilation
description: Tony and the Time Team review past episodes and look at the changing face of death and burial in Britain throughout the ages.

title: The Forgotten Gunners of WW1
description: Golfers at an East Midlands golf club want to know what the huge wooded bank beside their fairway is. TT experts discover, that 90 years ago it was a machine gun firing range - and buried in the bank are tens of thousands of spent bullets.

title: Brancaster, Norfolk
description: Tony and the team take a look around a site at Brancaster in Norfolk, which is believed to have been a Roman 'Shore-Fort' in the past.

title: Ely, Cardiff
description: Tony and the team investigate a large hill close to Cardiff that might be immensely significant as it could be the long-lost Iron Age capital of South Wales.

title: Henham House, Suffolk
description: Tony and the team attempt to help Hektor Rous, the son of 'Aussie Earl' Keith Rous, work out the mysterious history of the family's Tudor country home in Suffolk.

title: Barrow Clump, Salisbury Plain, Wiltshire
description: An ancient site that yields burials dating back to 2000BC, along with some rare Saxon brooches, beads, spears and jewelry is discovered on the army training ground on Salisbury Plain.

roles.char: Himself - Lead Archaeologist, Defence Infrastructure Organisation, MOD

title: Coniston, the Lake District
description: Tony and the team make their way to the Lake District on an expedition that takes them both higher and deeper than they've ever been before. They are looking for a forgotten piece of the nation's industrial heritage.

title: Oakham, Rutland
description: The team are at Oakham Castle, The best preserved 12th-century building in the country. There's more to it than meets the eye though as the walled area surrounding the castle is full of mysterious lumps and bumps waiting to be investigated.

title: Dropshort, Oxfordshire
description: In the 1960s, a young PhD student decided to excavate a South Oxfordshire field. He found a mosaic and the stone walls of what was clearly a Roman building. But he never found enough evidence to prove exactly what was there.

title: Dundrum, County Down
description: Tony and the team look for the remains of a renegade knight's Norman castle in one of Northern Ireland's most picturesque spots.

roles.char: Himself - Co-site Director, Queen's University Belfast
Himself - Principal Inspector, Northern Ireland Environment Agency

title: Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire
description: Tudor visitors remarked that it was grander than Hampton Court. But the palace went missing until the 1950s, when a group of pupils at Northwood School in Hertfordshire discovered its remains beneath their school playing field.

title: Upton Castle, Pembrokeshire
description: Steve and Pru fell in love with Upton Castle in Pembrokeshire and they had little idea what they had. Acres of overgrown gardens surrounded the building and looked like a medieval castle at the front and a Victorian mansion at the back.

title: The Time Team Guide to Experimental Archaeology
description: Tony celebrates more than 150 practical experiments and re-creations that he and the team have taken part in over the last 20 years.

title: 20 Years of Time Team
description: Tony takes a look back at the best bits from two decades and over 250 episodes.

title: A Time Team Special in Canterbury
Boudica's Lost Tribe: A Time Team Special
description: It was always thought Boudica's tribe was wiped out after a major uprising against Roman rule in Britain. Recent discoveries have begun to tell a different story and they may not have been the barbaric warriors of the Romans described.

title: Britain's Bronze Age Mummies: A Time Team Special
Britain's Drowned World: A Time Team Special

roles.char: Himself - Institute of Archaeology, University of Oxford
Herself - Pembrokeshire Coast National Park Archaeologist
Himself - Rotterdam Museum of Natural History
Himself - Hampshire & Wight Trust for Maritime Archaeology
Herself - Royal Holloway, University of London
Himself - Institute of Archaeology, University of Oxford

title: Britain's Lost Roman Circus: A Time Team Special
Britain's Stone Age Tsunami: A Time Team Special

roles.char: Himself - Marine Geologist, British Geological Survey

title: Brunel's Last Launch: A Time Team Special
Buried by the Blitz: A Time Team Special
description: Dorchester street in London's East End was a thriving community until the coming of the Blitz. Today all that is left is a park and aging memories of the time London went to war. The Time decide to uncover the history of the street, using excavations and eyewitness accounts.

title: Codename: Ainsbrook - A Time Team Special
Coventry's Lost Cathedral
description: A special return report on the axcavations on the 'lost' medieval cathedral in Coventry. The Time Team had previously broadcast on their own excavations in the programme broadcast as part of the general series on 13 February 2000 (Series 7, episode 7).

title: Dinosaur Hunting: A Time Team Special
Dover Castle: A Time Team Special
Hadrian's Well: A Time Team Special

roles.char: Himself - Former City of London Archaeologist
Herself - Author: The Other Boleyn Girl
Herself - Research Curator, Hampton Court Palace
Himself - Buildings Curator, Historic Royal Palaces
Himself - St Mary's University College, London

title: Island of the Eels: A Time Team Special
description: A documentary on a non-Time Team excavation in Ely, Cambridgeshire.

roles.char: Himself - Senior Archaeologist, Cambridge County Council

title: Journey to Stonehenge: A Time Team Special
King of Bling: A Time Team Special
Life on the Edge 1000 BC: A Time Team Special
Londinium: The Edge of Empire - A Time Team Special

roles.char: Himself - Project Manager: Museum of London Archaeology Service
Herself - Roman Curator: Museum of London
Herself - Managing Director: Museum of London Archaeology Service

title: Nelson's Hospital: A Time Team Special

roles.char: Herself - Scientific Dating Expert, English Heritage
Himself - Historical Re-Enactor, Legio II Augusta
Himself - Dorset Jurassic Coast Management Plan

title: Secrets of the Saxon Gold: A Time Team Special
Secrets of the Stately Garden: A Time Team Special
Shakespeare's House: A Time Team Special
description: The Time Team visit the site of Shakespeare's "Newplace" which was always assumed to be his home based on an 18th Century drawing. They quickly realize the dig is a lot more complex with a strong suggestion what was Shakespeare's house was in fact something completely different.

title: Steel City: A Time Team Special
Swords, Skulls & Strongholds: A Time Team Special
The Big Roman Villa: A Time Team Special
The Edwardian Grand Designer: A Time Team Special

roles.char: Himself - Architectural Advisor, Thiepval Visitor Centre
Herself - Author, 'New Delhi: Making of a Capital'

title: The God of Gothic: A Time Team Special
description: Augustus Pugin is renowned for his work glamorising the interiors of the Palace of Westminster, But although he died in 1852 at the age of only 40, there was much more to this prolific and and influential architect's CV. Tony Robinson tours the UK to explore Pugin's work and legacy, and follows the Landmark Trust as it sets out to restore Pugin's near-derelict family home, The Grange, in Ramsgate.

roles.char: Himself - Dean of St Chad's Cathedral

title: The House in the Loch: A Time Team Special
The Lost Dock of Liverpool: A Time Team Special

roles.char: Himself - Author, 'Sweets: A History of Temptation'

title: The Lost WWI Bunker: A Time Team Special
The Mystery of Mine Howe: A Time Team Special
The Mystery of Seahenge
description: A strange wooden structure was found protruding out of a beach, an urgent effort is made to save the monument from destruction by the sea. Archeologist must battle both atrocious conditions and negative feelings from locals as they work to move the object to safety. In the end everyone is deeply touched by the the structure and events surrounding its discovery.

title: The Real King Arthur
description: The Time Team review what we know about King Arthur, both as legend and reality. They explore the possible even more ancient history of the legend, including a remarkable reinterpretation of the drawing the sword from the stone.

title: The Real Knights of the Round Table: A Time Team Special

roles.char: Himself - Author: Edward III's Round Table

title: The Real Vikings: A Time Team Special
The Secret of Lincoln Jail: A Time Team Special
The Secrets of Stonehenge: A Time Team Special
The Secrets of Westminster Abbey: A Time Team Special

roles.char: Himself - Royal Holloway, University of London
Himself - Keeper of the Muniments, Westminster Abbey
Himself - Head of Abbey Collections, Westminster Abbey

title: The Somme's Secret Weapon: A Time Team Special
description: In 1916 a frightening new weapon is unleashed on the Germans by British forces. The Livens Flame projector was a terror weapon of amazing ability, yet no examples exist today. Members of the Time Team join an archeology team excavating remains of such a machine and then build a replica to test the weapons true potential

title: The Ten Million Pound House: A Time Team Special
The Wreck of Colossus: A Time Team Special
description: Colossus was one of Nelsons ships at Trafalgar, not long after the battle she sank in English waters. The Time Team join with other archaeologists to explore the wreck site and gain information of the giant statue found near the shipwreck.

roles.char: Himself - Curator of Naval History: National Maritime Museum, Greenwich

title: Time Team Christmas Special
description: Tony looks back at the highlights of the first 4 years of the Time Team. They revisit a number of digs and learn what happened to the finds they helped unearth and in some instance look at the extended work their episode sparked.

title: Time Team Special: The Mystery of the Roman Treasure
Wars of the Roses: A Time Team Special
description: Doubt is cast on the location of one of the most pivotal battles in English history, the battle of Bosworth Field. Tony follows researchers as they conduct a series of tests recreating cannon fire from the time to try and confirm their suspicion.
